title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Article Title
Stressor-Cortisol Concordance Among Individuals at Clinical High-Risk for Psychosis: Novel Findings from the NAPLS Cohort

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Key Terms

Concordance



Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal(HPA) axis The central physiological mechanism linking psychosocial stress to the onset and exacerbation of schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders



HPA dysregulation
HPA axis
Prodrome/ Prodromal

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Question

Broad Question

The neural diathesis stress model and clinical risk for psychosis Abnormalities in the HPA axis , places individuals at increased vulnerability for psychosis

Specific Question

Determining the extent to which HPA axis responsivity in at-risk youth predicts clinical outcome is important

CHR youth who later converted to psychosis would show:

Greater exposure and distress in relation to psychosocial stressors
Elevated basal cortisol
Higher stressor-cortisol concordance relative to healthy controls

CHR nonconverters

Would be intermediate to CHR converters subgroups and healthy controls



Measurement positive symptom progression

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Methods
Utilizing data from North American Prodrome Longitudinal Study 2 NAPLS 2
Subjects

662 participants
Age
CHR subjects


Exclusion criteria 1. Axis-1 psychotic disorder 2. Permitted treatment with antipsychotic medication provided full psychotic symptoms were not present at the time of medication commencement
Initial assessment 1. Conducted by clinically trained interviewers

2. Prodromal syndromes were assessed using the Criteria of Prodromal Syndromes (COPS) based on the Structured Interview for Prodromal Syndromes(SIPS)
3. Psychiatric diagnoses were determined via the Structured Clinical Interview (SCID) for DSM-IV

Help Seeking
Met criteria for one or more prodromal syndromes 1. Attenuated psychotic symptoms 2. Brief intermittent psychotic symptoms 3. Substantial functional decline combine with a first degree relative with a psychotic disorder or schizotypal personality disorder in individuals younger than 18 years.
